entry.title: How to Create a Decision Tree in BRF+
entry.content:
How to Create a Decision Tree in BRF+
1. Introduction

The Business Rule Framework Plus (BRF+) in SAP allows business users and developers to define and maintain business rules without extensive ABAP coding.
A Decision Tree is a graphical way of modeling conditional logic where each branch represents a decision point.

This manual explains how to create and test a Decision Tree in BRF+.

2. Launch BRF+ Workbench

Open SAP GUI.

Enter Transaction Code: BRF+ (or BRFPLUS).

The BRF+ Workbench opens in a browser-based window.

3. Create an Application

In the Workarea, select Create → Application.

Enter details such as:

Application Name: Z_DEMO_APP

Description: Demo application for decision tree

Package: $TMP (for local) or assign to a transport request

Save the application.

4. Create a Function

Inside the application, right-click and choose Create → Function.

Maintain the following:

Name: Z_DECISION_TREE_FUNC

Mode: Event Mode

Save the function.

5. Create a Decision Tree Object

Right-click on the function.

Select Create → Expression → Decision Tree.

Provide details:

Name: Z_DECISION_TREE

Description: Example for discount calculation

Save the object.

6. Define Input and Output Data Objects

Create input data objects for decision making, for example:

Order_Type (Data Type: CHAR)

Customer_Category (Data Type: CHAR)

Define an output object to hold the decision result, for example:

Discount_Value (Data Type: NUMC).

7. Model the Decision Tree Logic

Open the Decision Tree in the graphical editor.

Add branches and maintain conditions:

IF Order_Type = 'ONLINE' → Assign Discount_Value = 10.

IF Order_Type = 'RETAIL' → Assign Discount_Value = 5.

ELSE → Assign Discount_Value = 0.

Save and activate the decision tree.

8. Test the Decision Tree

Right-click on the decision tree and choose Test.

Enter test values, for example:

Order_Type = ONLINE

Customer_Category = GOLD

Execute and verify the result returned in Discount_Value.

9. Conclusion

We have successfully created a Decision Tree in BRF+.
This object can now be used in business functions to replace hard-coded logic, making it easier to maintain and update rules without changing ABAP code.

For complex business rules, you may also explore Decision Tables or Formulas in BRF+.

entry.content:
Hi Chhatru,

 

The APP VT01N is not available in SAP Public Cloud. Please check details in KBA 3261640 - Usage of LE-TRA Route and discontinuation of Transportation features of LE-TRA in public cloud

The transportation features of LE-TRA, especially the shipment and the shipment cost document, including all necessary objects, Master data, customizing and transactions, are not released in the S/4HANA Public Cloud.

It is recommended to use SAP Transportation Management functionality in S/4HANA Public Cloud.

You may find all TM related Best Practice scope items from:

https://me.sap.com/processnavigator/SolS/EARL_SolS-013 -> Navigate to Supply Chain -> Delivery and Transportation.

And please check the Help documentation of Transportation Management for all the details:

Help Documentation - Transportation Management (TM)

 

Best Regards,

Jennifer

entry.title: Master Data Management via Business Data Cloud: Datasphere & Seamless Planning in combination
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere and SAC Seamless Planning will play an increasingly important role in the future. Since Seamless Planning is still a relatively young product, its current interaction capabilities with SAP Datasphere are limited. Nevertheless, this example demonstrates how master data from SAP Datasphere can already be enriched and managed using Seamless Planning.

Setup SAP Datasphere

Let us assume that we have two tables in SAP Datasphere:

  • Customer Table
    • CustomerNumber
    • CustomerName
    • Country
    • RegionCode
  • Region Table
    • RegionCode
    • Description

Our goal is to assign regions to customers via Seamless Planning and maintain the description of the regions.

To achieve this, we create local tables for both dimensions and expose them through fact view and analytical model for SAC consumption. (For the fact view, we simply added a row counter as a key figure.)

  1. Customer Table
  2. Customer Fact View
  3. Customer Analytical Model

SAC Data Preview:

And like this for the Region Model

  1. Region Table
  2. Region Fact View
  3. Region Analytical Model

SAC Data Preview:

Setup SAP Analytics Cloud

In SAC we also create two dimensions, one for Customer Region Assignment and one for the Region. We then expose both to SAP Datasphere.

The dimension for the Customer Region Assignment looks like this in SAC:

It also has a property with region:

The Dimension for Region looks like this:

We then also create a Dummy Planning Model which will hold our dimension and Dummy Keyfigure as it is required. This one is also exposed to SAP Datasphere.

Setup Planning Application in SAP Analytics Cloud

We then build a story in SAC, including:

  • The two analytical models (Customer and Region)
  • The dummy planning model

Tables with the data can be displayed (or hidden in a real application).

Customer Region Assignment

In the Customer Region Assignment tab, we add two dropdowns, one for the Customer Selection and one for the Region it should be assigned. On the initialization we fill the dropdowns with the following script:

var customers = Customer.getDataSource().getMembers("CustomerNumber");
var customerName = Customer.getDataSource().getMembers("CustomerName");

console.log(customers);

for (var i = 0; i<customers.length;i++){
	CustomerDropdown.addItem(customers[i].displayId, customerName[i].displayId);
	
}

var regions = Region.getDataSource().getMembers("RegionCode");
console.log(regions);


for (var j = 0; j<regions.length;j++){
	RegionDropdown.addItem(regions[j].displayId);
	
}

This way the dropdown gets filled with our Data from the Analytical Models and the dimension values from SAP Datasphere.

An Assignment could then be done by selecting the Customer and the Region.

When the Save button is pressed the script performs the following actions and updates the dimension:

var region = RegionDropdown.getSelectedKey();
var customer = CustomerDropdown.getSelectedKey();
var customerText = CustomerDropdown.getSelectedText();

console.log(region);
console.log(customer);

CustomerInput=({id:customer, description:customerText ,properties:{Region:region}});
console.log(CustomerInput);

DummyModel.updateMembers("CustomerRegionAssignment",CustomerInput);

As the dimension is stored in Datasphere we can now see the values in the Seamless planning table.

We now add this table in a Transformation flow as Source and add this information to our original Datasphere table which holds the Customer Information.

Region Text Maintenance

In this tab we do something very similar. We add one Dropdown to select for which region you want to maintain the text and one text input to maintain it. The dropdown is again filled upon initialization of the page with the following script:

var regions = RegionText.getDataSource().getMembers("RegionCode");
var regionsText = RegionText.getDataSource().getMembers("Description");

for (var j = 0; j<regions.length;j++){
	RegionTextDropdown.addItem(regions[j].displayId, regionsText[j].displayId);
	
}

And that based on the selection the text input is filled:

var sel = RegionTextDropdown.getSelectedText();
console.log(sel);

RegionTextMaint.setValue(sel);

In the application this looks like:

Upon the Button execution the dimension is updated:

var region = RegionTextDropdown.getSelectedKey();
var regionText = RegionTextMaint.getValue();

console.log(region);
console.log(regionText);

RegionTextInput=({id:region, description:regionText});
console.log(CustomerInput);

DummyModel.updateMembers("Region",RegionTextInput);

Identical to the example above the value is then stored in SAP Datasphere and a Transformation Flow writes the value into its original table:

Conclusion and Outlook

In practice, transformation flows could be triggered through a task chain, initiated by a multi-action in SAC. This will become easier once SAP provides an API to trigger task chains, or by using our solution to wrap the task chain CLI (Link ZPARTNER; Link SAP Community).

Looking ahead, the goal is for transformation flows to become unnecessary—enabling direct master data management in Seamless Planning, similar to the functionality available in SAP BW/4HANA.

Even though Seamless Planning is still a young functionality, with some creativity and ideation, it already offers ways to enrich SAP Datasphere data and design new planning processes using SAP’s latest cloud technology stack.

entry.title: Re: 2025 Update: Alternatives to Scope Item 2JD (Fiori An...
entry.content:
Hello @sergio21 

Thank you for your question.

The 2508 “Whats New” document for the 2508 release confirms the removal of 2JD. Its analytical capabilities are now provided through standard Fiori apps and embedded analytics.

To answer your question on if these functionalities now integrated into standard SAP Fiori apps, Embedded Analytics. The answer is yes. You can consult The 2508 “Whats New” document for more details.

In 2508, the planning Tabel for repetitive manufacturing is highlighted as a key tool because it gives visibility into run schedules, material flow etc. Which means some aspects of planning analytics are delivered through these newer tools.

For example, 2QW was mentioned to potentially cover a subset of what 2JD did in the past especially in cost vs plan tracking.

Standard apps around MRP, capacity planning, production etc., now include more built-in monitoring or analytic tile that would have previously been in overview apps provided by 2JD. This suggest that SAP seems to be consolidating analytics closer to operation rather than via separate overview scope items.

Below are checks you may consider (recommendations)

  • Identify which specific KPIs or overview pages you used under 2JD
  • Search for equivalent standard apps/Fiori tiles in your system that have embedded analytics or dashboards.
  • Check the Fiori Launchpad catalogs under production planning to see what monitoring apps are available.
  • Use configuration apps or embedded setup to see if the metrics you need are exposed.
  • If some analytics are missing, consider whether you need SAC, custom CDS or custom analytics to fill the gaps.

Consult these references for more details.

Overview of Analytical Applications

SAP Help – Deprecated Scope Items

SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP 分析云新增提醒功能，助您轻松管理数据更改日志
entry.content:
在已经发布的2025 年 QRC3 版本中，SAP 分析云全新推出“数据更改日志通知”功能，可在日志规模演变成问题前，第一时间发出提醒，让维护计划环境的健康更轻松。 

概述   

您现在可以配置提醒，当数据更改日志达到指定大小时主动通知您。这一点在多人协作的大型计划环境中尤其实用——持续的计划操作与频繁发布极易导致数据更改日志大小快速增长。 

借助这些提醒，您将获得： 

  • 模型健康状况的更高透明度   
  • 在问题出现前主动缩减日志大小的控制权 
  • 避免因日志过大而导致发布受阻的频繁中断 

配置管理   

管理通知配置   

具备相关权限的管理员或用户可通过以下路径配置数据更改日志提醒：   

系统 > 管理 > 通知 > 数据更改日志通知 

在这里，您可以：   

  • 自定义阈值大小   
  • 选择通知方式（应用内、电子邮件或两者）   
  • 指定需要接收通知的人员 

提示：为避免打扰用户，建议将阈值至少设为 60%，默认值为 80%。 

电子邮件通知的用户首选项设置 

对于“数据更改日志”对象类型具有“删除”权限的用户，或被手动添加到自定义收件人列表中的用户，可通过以下路径管理个人邮件首选项： 

个人资料设置 > 用户首选项 > 数据更改日志通知 

在这里，用户可以根据需要开启或关闭电子邮件通知。 

结果 

当任意模型的数据更改日志达到设定阈值时，系统会自动触发通知。 

当您收到通知时，建议尽快缩小日志大小，以免在发布数据时受到干扰。您可以导航到“数据更改日志”来执行此操作，借助灵活的筛选条件快速定位并删除日志记录；如需留档，可先将记录导出备份。 

结论 

借助这一全新的通知功能，您可以更有效地监控数据更改日志的健康状态，保障系统持续稳定运行。 

 

原文作者：Sarau 

原文链接：https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/new-alert-helps-you-manage-data-change-logs-easily-in-sac-analytics-cloud/ba-p/14152401

entry.title: Re: Stock in transit with moving average in SAP S4HANA
entry.content:
When you post a 107 movement, the goods are recorded in Valuated GR Blocked Stock. This means:

Financially: The value of the goods is recognised in our books immediately, as ownership has transferred.

Operationally: The stock is not yet available for production or sales, and MRP does not consider it.

Because the stock is valuated, the system’s Moving Average Price (MAP) calculation in the material master will reflect it; the MAP is always based on all valuated stock, regardless of whether it is available or blocked.

However, this does not distort the MAP for available stock because:

  • the quantity is still segregated in GR Blocked Stock and cannot be consumed.
  • the MAP change is “pre‑loaded” at the point of ownership transfer, so when we later post the 109 movement (physical arrival), there is no second financial impact and no additional MAP change.

In other words, the 107/109 process ensures that:

  • you comply with accounting rules by recognising ownership at the correct time.
  • you avoid double‑impacting the MAP.
  • you keep unavailable stock out of operational planning until it physically arrives.

So to clarify your query on how to check, perform the below steps

Before 107

  • Run MB52 or Display Stock Overview (MMBE) for the material.
  • Note unrestricted stock qty/value and GR blocked stock qty/value.

After 107

  • MMBE will show the quantity/value in GR Blocked Stock.
  • Unrestricted stock qty/value is unchanged.
  • MM03 MAP will reflect the combined valuated stock.

After 109

  • MMBE will show the quantity/value moved to unrestricted.
  • No FI document is posted — MAP remains the same as after 107.

entry.content:
The SI Payment Details & related tabs are located within the Company Code data of the Business Partner.

  1. Open the "Maintain Business Partner" application.
  2. Select the Business Partner with ID 18537001.
  3. Navigate to the role "Counterparty".
  4. Access the "Company Code" section.
  5. Verify that the SI Payment Details and related tabs are now visible.

entry.title: Profiling with the Cloud Foundry CLI Java plugin
entry.content:
Welcome back to my post on profiling your Java applications in Cloud Foundry and the tool I helped to develop to make it easier.

Cloud Foundry "is an open source, multi-cloud application platform as a service (PaaS) governed by the Cloud Foundry Foundation, a 501(c)(6) organization" (Wikipedia). It allows you to run your workloads easily in the cloud, including your Java applications. You just need to define a manifest.yml, like for example:

---
applications:
- name: sapmachine21
  random-route: true
  path: test.jar
  memory: 512M
  buildpacks: 
  - sap_java_buildpack
  env:
    TARGET_RUNTIME: tomcat
    JBP_CONFIG_COMPONENTS: "jres: ['com.sap.xs.java.buildpack.jdk.SAPMachineJDK']"
    JBP_CONFIG_SAP_MACHINE_JDK : "{ version: 21.+ }"
    JBP_CONFIG_JAVA_OPTS: "[java_opts: '-XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions -XX:+DebugNonSafepoints']"

But how would you profile this application? This and more is the topic of this blog post.

I will not discuss why you might want to use Cloud Foundry or how you can deploy your own applications. I assume you came this far in the blog post because you already have basic Cloud Foundry knowledge and want to learn how to profile your applications easily.

The Java Plugin

Cloud Foundry has a cf CLI with a proper plugin system with lots of plugins. A team at SAP, which included Tim Gerrlach, started to develop the Java plugin many years ago at SAP. It's a plugin offering utilities to gain insights into JVMs running in your Cloud Foundry app.

You can simply install it via the official plugin repository (more in the README) :

cf install-plugin java

It started with support for heap-dumps and thread-dumps:

> cf java heap-dump $APP_NAME
-> ./$APP_NAME-heapdump-$RANDOM.hprof

This remotely creates a heap dump and downloads it. You can view these files using tools like the Eclipse Memory Analyzer.

> cf java thread-dump $APP_NAME
...
Full thread dump OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM ...
...

This command obtains and prints a thread dump that you can use to analyze the currently running threads of your applications. You can visualize these dumps with tools like Samurai.

Please be aware that this only works if you use a SAPJVM/SapMachine JRE/JDK or a non-SapMachine JDK. Only SapMachine JREs are guaranteed to include the necessary Java command-line tools that the Java plugin requires.

Profiling your Applications

But wouldn't it be nice to profile your applications directly via the Java plugin? This is why the SapMachine Team took over the development of the CF plugin. We wanted to make it as easy as possible to record profiles without having to use cf ssh into the Java application only to then manually download the recordings. This is cumbersome and error-prone.

So with the newest releases of the CF plugin, you have the power of JFR and Async-Profiler at your fingertips.

But please remember that we focus on SapMachine here.

 

Profiling with JFR

To profile a Java application and obtain the JFR file, you can simply use the jfr-* commands of the plugin (via cf java --help):

  • jfr-start: Start a basic Java Flight Recorder profile on a running Java application
  • jfr-start-profile: Start a recording with the profile.jfc setting, that records more information and has shorter profiling intervals
  • jfr-start-gc: Start a recording with gc.jfc (SapMachine only) which focuses on garbage collection events
  • jfr-start-gc-details: More garbage collection details
  • jfr-stop: Stop a Java Flight Recorder recording on a running Java application and download the recording
  • jfr-dump: jfr-stop without stopping the application
  • jfr-status: Check whether there is a running Java Flight Recorder recording

To, for example, check the status of the recording, you can run:

> cf java thread-dump $APP_NAME
No available recordings.
Use jcmd ... JFR.start to start a recording.

A simple profiling workflow usually looks like the following:

# Start recording
> cf java jfr-start $APP_NAME
# Interact with the application
...
# Stop and download the recording
> cf java jfr-stop $APP_NAME
-> creates a JFR file in your current local folder

You can then view the JFR files, either with the OpenJDK's own jfr tool, JDK Mission Control, our Plugin for IntelliJ, as well as many other Java profiling tools.

The jfr-* commands work with non-SapMachine OpenJDK distributions' JDK too.

Profiling with Async-Profiler

Last year, the SapMachine team decided to include a build of Async-Profiler directly into our JDK and JRE builds to make profiling Java applications as easy as possible. It has another benefit too: We can use Async-Profiler's native version of the Java tool jcmd, so we don't need to start another JVM just to trigger a heap dump or thread dump. But back to the profiling. The CF plugin offers commands for Async-Profiler that are similar to the ones for JFR:

  • asprof-start-cpu: Start a CPU-time Async-Profiler recording on a running Java application, creating a JFR file
  • asprof-start-wall: Start a wall-clock recording (similar to JFR method profiling)
  • asprof-start-alloc: Start an allocation profile that helps you to find heap polluting classes
  • asprof-start-lock: Start a lock profile that tracks whenever code obtains a lock
  • asprof-status: Check whether there is a running Async-Profiler recording

A typical profiling workflow looks not too different from the previous JFR profiling workflow:

# Start recording
> cf java asprof-start-cpu $APP_NAME
# Interact with the application
...
# Stop and download the recording
> cf java asprof-stop $APP_NAME
-> creates a JFR file in your current local folder

There is also the asprof command that allows you to use Async-Profiler directly. But I would not recommend using it if any of the other commands are sufficient, as getting it right on the first try is pretty complicated and challenging.

The asprof-* commands only work on non-SapMachines if your Java distribution includes the asprof binary.

Other Commands

Three other CF plugin commands might be interesting:

> cf java vm-info $APP_NAME
#
# JRE version: OpenJDK Runtime Environment SapMachine (21.0.7+6) (build 21.0.7+6-LTS)
# Java VM: OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM SapMachine (21.0.7+6-LTS, mixed mode, sharing, tiered, compressed oops, compressed class ptrs, serial gc, linux-amd64)
...

vm-info gives you lots of information on the current state of the JVM running your application.

> cf java vm-version $APP_NAME
OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM version 21.0.7+6-LTS
JDK 21.0.7

vm-version gives you information on the current OpenJDK version that you're running.

> cf java vm-version $APP_NAME
Vitals:

------------system------------
           avail: Memory available without swapping [host] [krn]
            comm: Committed memory [host]
             crt: Committed-to-Commit-Limit ratio (percent) [host]
            swap: Swap space used [host]
              si: Number of pages swapped in [host] [delta]
              so: Number of pages pages swapped out [host] [delta]
               p: Number of processes
...

vm-vitals prints many JVM process statistics collected over the last 60 minutes and more coarsely over the previous days, but only on SapMachines.

The jcmd command also allows you to use the jcmd Java utility directly, but I would advise against using it directly, as with the asprof command.

Limitations

Of course, the plugin has limitations. For example, to get accurate profiles, you want to add the following to your application definition YAML:

JBP_CONFIG_JAVA_OPTS: "[java_opts: '-XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions -XX:+DebugNonSafepoints']"

Adapted from the plugin README:

The filesystem available to the container also limits the capability of creating heap dumps and profiles. The cf java heap-dump, cf java asprof-stop, and cf java jfr-stop commands trigger a write to the file system, read the content of the file over the SSH connection, and then remove the file from the container's file system (unless you have the -k flag set).

The amount of filesystem space available to a container is set for the entire Cloud Foundry landscape with a global configuration. The size of a heap dump is roughly linear with the allocated memory of the heap, and the profile size is related to the length of the recording. So, it could be that, in case of large heaps, long profiling durations, or the filesystem having too much stuff in it, there is not enough space on the filesystem for creating the file. In that case, the creation of the heap dump or profile recording, and thus the command, will fail.

From the perspective of integration in workflows and overall shell-friendliness, the plugin suffers from some shortcomings in the current cf-cli plugin framework:

  • There is no distinction between stdout and stderr output from the underlying cf ssh command (see this issue on the cf-cli project)
    • The plugin will, however, mostly exit with status code 1 when the underpinning cf ssh command fails
    • If split between stdout and stderr is needed, you can run the cf java plugin in dry-run mode (--dry-run flag) and execute its output instead

Of course, running the commands has side effects. Please refer to the CF plugin README.

Please be aware that the CF Java plugin is mainly used (and tested) in combination with SapMachine; none of the plugin's features currently work with non-SapMachine/SAPJVM JREs, and only some work with non-SapMachine JDKs.

Testing a Cloud Foundry CLI Plugin

By now, you're hopefully convinced that the CF Java plugin is really useful. But how is the plugin tested to make it works?

Before the significant rewrite that added the profiling features, the plugin was tested by mocking some functions and checking that the executed SSH commands were the expected ones. This worked well enough while the plugin was small, but hard-coding all the used SSH commands became unsustainable with the growing list of commands.

Therefore, we nowadays test the plugin directly without mocking with a small Java application. The CF plugin is written in Go, but the test cases are deliberately written in Python to use the CF plugin as a black box. The test code includes a custom black-box testing framework for CF plugins.

To give you an example: The test case that checks that the Async-Profiler workflow from above works is written as follows

class TestAsprofBasic(TestBase):
    # ...
    
    (no_restart=True)
    def test_basic_profile(self, t, app):
        """Test basic async-profiler profile start and stop."""
        # Start profiling
        t.run(f"asprof-start-cpu {app}") \ # run a command
         .should_succeed() \               # error code 0 
         .should_contain(f"Use 'cf java asprof-stop {app}'") \
         .no_files()                       # no local or remote files created 

        # Clean up
        t.run(f"asprof-stop {app}") \
         .should_succeed() \
         .should_create_file("*.jfr") \ # a JFR file is created locally
         .should_create_no_remote_files()

The goal for the tests is to be as readable as possible, so they also function as documentation. Feel free to peek into the test suite to find all the tested workflows.

Issues?

The CF plugin is open to feature requests/suggestions, bug reports, etc. via GitHub issues. Contribution and feedback are encouraged and always welcome. Just be aware that this plugin is limited in scope to keep it maintainable. For more information about how to contribute, the project structure, and additional contribution information, see our Contribution Guidelines.

If you find a bug that may be a security problem, please follow the instructions in our security policy on how to report it. Please do not create GitHub issues for security-related doubts or problems.

Conclusion

The Cloud Foundry CLI Java plugin lets you easily profile your Java application and obtain heap and thread dumps. It builds on top of the SapMachine to make running applications, like those based on CAP, easier in Cloud Foundry cloud environments.

entry.title: Why People Come Before Process and Technology in the SAP BTP Journey
entry.content:
When people talk about SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) or any transformation project, the conversation often begins with technology—data models, extensions, integrations, and AI. But in my experience, the real magic of BTP doesn’t just come from its capabilities; it comes from the people who gather around it.

A platform becomes powerful when it inspires collaboration. That’s where community building comes in. Whether you’re a developer, architect, or business user, being part of a thriving community accelerates learning, drives adoption, and sparks innovation in ways no single project team can achieve alone.

Who I Am

I’m SAP BTP DevOps & AI Manager at Bluestonex (member of the SAP AppHaus Network), a mentor guiding SAP Tech professionals at Modish Tech (my own digital brand), and a trustee for The Sanatan Parivar charity, aiming to bring communities together.

I’ve been fortunate to see SAP BTP evolve from its very beginnings, and I’m thankful to the organisations I worked for—and continue to work with—for allowing me to explore it right from when it was first introduced. 

My passion lies in bridging innovation with community impact—using technology not just to solve business challenges, but also to empower people. Over the years, I’ve seen how focusing on people first changes the trajectory of projects, communities, and careers.

If you’d like to continue the conversation or just say hello, you can find me on LinkedIn.

Now, back to the topic...

Technology Is Only Part of the Equation

SAP BTP offers incredible capabilities that reshape business operations. But these tools are only as effective as the people who imagine, build, and sustain them. Without shared understanding, collaboration, and knowledge transfer, even the most advanced solutions risk becoming underutilised—or worse, becoming that “cool proof of concept” everyone forgets about six months later.

The People-First Advantage

So what does “people first” look like in the SAP BTP journey?

  • Confidence Through Enablement – These days, enablement is the key. With an ever-changing tech stack—and especially in the SAP ecosystem, where constant branding and rebranding often push older content into the bin—newcomers are left confused about where to start. Classic example is SAP Integration Suite in the community is known by different names, CPI, IS, CI... everyone has their own version. We still refer Work Zone as the launchpad.  These are just few examples, I hear a lot from my mentees. This is why consistent enablement matters. Without it, people struggle to build confidence; with it, they can navigate the shifts, embrace the new, and grow faster.
  • Knowledge Sharing – Empowering teams through open discussions, blogs, and mentorship ensures that expertise doesn’t sit in silos. It's easy to explore technology and build a proof of concept individually. But if we multiply this, it's even more powerful. This means everyone in a team is doing it, think about the productivity and work delivered by  the team.
  • Collaboration Over Isolation – The best BTP outcomes I’ve seen came from cross-functional teams and communities working together, not from lone experts. Let's be real, you cannot do everything on your own. You need people with expertise in different areas. 
  • Innovation Through Conversation – Some of the most creative BTP use cases I’ve seen didn’t start with a specification sheet; they started with people brainstorming and challenging each other. An example of this is the SAP BTP Monitor, which the team at Bluestonex delivered when we had nothing where we can see the SAP BTP consumption. Now SAP have come up with this option in the cockpit. There are many gaps, and people at Bluestonex fill these gaps with apps, all that starts with a conversation!

Rethinking the Balance

Process and technology will always matter—but they’re accelerators, not starting points. When you put people first, you create an environment where processes can adapt and technologies can scale. Skip the people, and you risk building solutions that look great on paper but struggle in practice.

Building a Community That Lasts

That’s why community matters so much in the SAP BTP journey. Communities create ecosystems where growth is mutual—where experts share not just what they know, but also lift others to succeed. By doing so, they multiply value far beyond what technology alone can deliver.

This is why I’ve chosen to write here. My goal is to contribute to a community where knowledge flows openly and people feel empowered to innovate together. In future posts, I’ll share practical ways to accelerate BTP learning and adoption, grounded in the belief that people must always come first.

Join the Conversation

SAP BTP will continue to evolve, but one principle remains constant: people drive progress.

So, I’ll leave you with this question: In your SAP BTP journey, how have people made a difference?

Your story might be the one that inspires someone else to grow. And if nothing else, you’ll save someone from endlessly googling “Is it still called SAP Cloud Platform or…?” 😉

entry.title: How to jumpstart with SAP RISE on SAP Cloud ALM adapting clean core principles
entry.content:
Structure of this blog

This blog is structured to understand the following:

  • What is SAP Rise?
  • SAP RISE with Cloud ALM
  • Enable Cloud ALM with Rise Compliance
  • RISE with SAP Dashboarding overview
  • What is in the Roadmap?

What is SAP Rise?

RISE with SAP is designed to help clients transition existing SAP systems (R/3, ECC or S/4 on-premise) to the cloud, to modernize ERP usage, and increase flexibility. Its objective is to upgrade clients’ legacy ERP systems to an AI-enabled cloud ERP. 

It’s a (BTaaS) Business-transformation-as-a-service offering, which helps businesses receive a tailored path to modernizing their implementation and operations.

Why is RISE with SAP Important for Clients?

RISE with SAP helps larger organizations move SAP systems to the cloud by offering an all-in-one package. It simplifies the migration process, making it easier to manage without the need for separate licenses.

What Kinds of Customers Can Benefit from SAP RISE?

1) Customers who are looking for transition to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud but have not yet begun their transition process.

2) Customers who are currently leveraging SAP ECC business processes but are planning to improve their digital transformation efforts with RISE.

3) Customers are planning to leverage hyper-scaler solutions, like Microsoft Azure or the Google Cloud Platform, to implement and integrate their new SAP S/4HANA Cloud solution across teams.

SAP RISE with Cloud ALM

For the customers moving to SAP Rise, Cloud ALM is a mandate.

SAP Cloud ALM provides the following to jump start the journey on RISE:

  • 'RISE with SAP Methodology” roadmap with clean core success plan to manage the corresponding Quality Gates.
  • Activate implementation methodology ensuring a Fit-to-Standard approach (for system conversion, greenfield, selective data transition).
  • SAP Best Practice processes as basis for Fit-to-Standard workshops (BPMNs, process documentation, test cases).
  • Tracking capabilities and Requirement Management for Fit-to-Standard workshops.
  • Analytics and Traceability dashboards to track the adherence to clean core criteria throughout the project.
  • Business Process Monitoring which is based on the pre-defined  business process KPIs.
  • Integration with SAP Readiness Check to get full traceability on simplification items, required custom code adoption, and add-ons.

Enable Cloud ALM to be Rise Compliant

To be RISE Compliant it is necessary to implement Project Management on Cloud ALM and work on the corresponding Q-Gates with the defined checklists.

  • Create a Project on Cloud ALM, choose the SAP Activate Roadmap:

 

  • Create a Scope and choose the Solution Scenarios

 

 

  • Populate the Timeboxes

 

 

  • Assign the teams as per the SOD’s

 

  • Assign the roadmap tasks to the onboarded team members and review the  roadmap task to check the standard tasks, create additional ones if required or mark not relevant tasks as obsolete.

 

 

 

  • Once the tasks are being assigned to the required team members and as they start working and closing the assigned tasks. We have reached the end of Prepare Phase of the project and now it’s time to review Quality Gates as per the RISE Compliance process. The Quality Gates are predefined and scheduled as per the timeboxes for each phase. We can also create additional Quality Gates with Checklists if required.

 

  • After Q-gate 1 is closed for the prepare phase of the project. SDR gets generated under Serviceà Service Delivery Center

 

 

 

  • Review the generated results in the report. The rating of the report gets generated as per the responses in Checklist of the Q-gates. Be cautious while filling out the responses.

 

 

  • SAP creates, follow up Actions as per the responses in the Checklist to re-submit the responses as per SAP standards to be RISE Compliant.

  • Take the necessary actions and close the open tasks/ checklist items to get the report status re-generated.
  • SAP also recommends leveraging additional Cloud ALM functionalities such as Requirements Management, Test Management, Release Management, etc.

RISE with SAP Dashboarding overview

The "RISE with SAP" Dashboard with SAP Cloud ALM is a tool designed to support SAP customers on their cloud transformation journey, focusing on maintaining a clean core and ensuring cloud compliance and upgrade readiness.

The dashboard gives an overview of: 

System View Dashboard: Provides an overview of system compliance, covering SAP S/4HANA systems in various environments (production, test, development). It tracks data collection status and supports SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Setting up System View dashboard. the technical requirements for data collection in the dashboard are:

  • EWA Generation: Enable the Early Watch Alert (EWA) setup and ensure EWA data is sent to SAP. Refer to SAP Note 207223.
  • Custom Code Analytics: Activate analytics based on EWA data. Refer to SAP Note 2947886.
  • ABAP Call Monitor (SCMON😞 Enable ABAP Call Monitor for detailed usage insights. Refer to SAP Note 2679723.
  • Aggregated Usage Data: Set up aggregated usage data collection. Refer to SAP Note 2701371.

Operation View Dashboard: Offers operational insights, KPIs, and ratings related to system health and compliance on the operational side.

The Operations View dashboard collects several metrics on a daily basis to calculate and display the overall System Health score, a percentage representing the average health of all your eligible systems. The score is a weighted mean based on different KPIs, such as Connectivity, Exceptions, Background Processing, and Performance.

  • Setting up Operations View dashboard. the technical requirements for data collection in the dashboard are:Solution Tools Plug-In (ST-PI) add-on installed on eligible systems: ST-PI 740 SP28.
  • Systems are connected to SAP Cloud ALM.
  • Data Collections is turned on in Health Monitoring.
  • Ativatate Systems in Integration & Exception Monitoring 
  • ABAP Runtime, ABAP System Log, and ABAP Application Log metrics are activated and enabled.

 

What is in the Roadmap?

Executive Dashboard: To get an overview of the executive-level summaries and strategic decision-making.

Key Takeaways:

  • RISE with SAP is enhanced with Clean Core Principles
  • It is evolving to be powered by Generative-AI 
  • Analyze detailed insights and data on the clean core status of system with the dashboards.

I hope this blog helps you find all the required information on how to be RISE compliant with SAP Cloud ALM.

Please ask for any clarifying questions regarding the blog in the comment section.

entry.title: Re: How to Add Text IDs for Customer Master (KNA1) in SAP...
entry.content:
Please note, in the Public Edition, the configuration for general customer texts is not exposed in CBC/SSCUI; it’s part of SAP’s “restricted configuration” that is only editable in on‑premise or Private Cloud. This means you cannot add new Text IDs for KNA1 yourself via CBC; you can only use the standard delivered ones.

Instead, what you can do is check the delivered general text IDs for customers in the Maintain Business Partner app → Customer role → Texts tab. If one of the delivered IDs can be repurposed, you can rename it in the UI (description only) and use it for your requirement.

On the other hand, if your process accepts sales area–specific storage, you can create a new Text ID via SSCUI 105683 and maintain it in the sales area texts section.

entry.title: ILM Store Configuration For Azure Blob
entry.content:
SAP ILM Store with Microsoft Azure Storage

1   Introduction

This document describes how to configure ILM store with Azure Blob

1.1     Purpose

The SAP Information Lifecycle Management (ILM) Store enables you to run the entire data retention process from data archiving and storing to their destruction, thus enabling data management through its lifecycle. This process takes into consideration SAP ILM Retention Management (RM) specifications.

You can use the WebDAV interface standard to store archive files in a Microsoft Azure storage account using Blob storage. This guide explains how to configure the ILM Store with a Microsoft Azure Blob storage account.

The SAP ILM Store with Microsoft Azure Storage

The system landscape can be configured in various ways, such as:

  • The archiving client, the Storage and Retention Service (SRS), and the ILM Store reside on the same system.
  • Using remote SRS to isolate the archiving client and the SRS.
  • The archiving client and the SRS reside on the same system, while the ILM Store is on a separate system.

This document explains how to configure the ILM Store with a Microsoft Azure storage account.

1.2     Scope

OS: SUSE Linux

Database: SAP HANA 2.0 SP6

Storage: Azure Blob

Platform: Azure Cloud

1.3     Acronyms and Definitions

Few of the acronyms and / or its definitions provided here may not have been used in this document but has been provided for easy reference to their definitions.

1.3.1     Acronyms

 

Acronym

Description

ILM

Information Lifecycle Management

SRS

Storage Retention Service

 

2  References

Installation and Configuration Guide for the ILM Store

Quick Configuration Guide for the ILM Store

ILM Store Troubleshooting

 

 

3  Prerequisites

Ensure that the following pre-requisites are met:

  1. Use a SAP S/4HANA 2021 system or an ABAP PLATFORM 2021 system.

For our case we have S/4 HANA 2021 System on NW 756

  1. Belo Business functions  needs to be activated

Information Lifecycle Management (ILM)

ILM Database Store (ILM_STOR) required to be activated.

2. Below SICF service required to be activated

3. You have a Microsoft Azure Blob Storage account set up.

 

4  Authorizations

Lists the authorizations required for configuring the ILM Store and storing files.

  We need a technical user with the necessary authorization to access the ILM Store and to upload files to the store. Assign a role to a user with the following authorizations:

 

Authorization Object

Field

Value

SILMSTOR

ACTVT

16 (Execute)

S_DATASET

FILENAME

*

PROGRAM

CL_ILM_STOR_DATASET===========CP

RILM_STOR_PUT_WORKER

ACTVT

6 (Delete), 33 (Read), 34 (Write)

S_DEVELOP

OBJTYP

TABL

ACTVT

07, 40

S_CTS_ADMI

CTS_ADMFCT

TABL

S_CTS_SADM

CTS_ADMFCT

TABL

We have a user in our system created SAP_DARCH_IMD

 

5   Storage Connection

Administrative data of the archive files is stored in the system database tables. The archive file data is stored as Blobs (Binary Large Object) in the configured Microsoft Azure Storage Account.

 

5.1   Exporting Certificates

Two required certificates need to be exported to later import them into the SAP S/4HANA system. Access the Microsoft Azure Portal and log into your account.

Below are the certificates.

  • OAuth 2.0 authorization
  • Blob service

End points from the Microsoft Azure Portal as shown below.

Copy the URL shown in screenshot, paste it to your browser and press enter.

  1. Click on the lock icon in the address bar.
  2. Click on Certificate sand a new window will open.
  3. Go to the tab Certification Path.
  4. Select Digi Cert, click on View Certificate and a new window will open.
  5. Go to Details and click on Copy to File.
  6. Save the certificate file(.CER) locally.

It should look like below.

Locate the Blob service of the primary endpoint

 

Copy the URL shown in screenshot, paste it to your browser and press enter.

  1. Click on the lock icon in the address bar.
  2. Click on Certificate sand a new window will open.
  3. Go to the tab Certification Path.
  4. Select Digi Cert, click on View Certificate and a new window will open.
  5. Go to Details and click on Copy to File.
  6. Save the certificate file(.CER) locally.

Certificate should look like below

These two certificates will have to be uploaded to the ILM Store.

Next, log into the SAP S/4HANA system with a user with the necessary authorizations to configure the ILM Store.

 

5.2   Importing Certificates

In the SAP S/4HANA system, you need to import the previously exported certificates to establish a connection between the systems using HTTPS. To ensure a secure connection using the OAuth 2.0 client, you must use a SSL/TLS communication channel between your service provider (Microsoft Azure in this case) and the Application Server ABAP.

 

Follow the steps below to upload the certificates:

  1. Start transaction STRUST.
  2. Import the certificates downloaded in the previous step.
  3. Save the certificates under the node “SSL Client SSL Client (Standard)”.

 

5.3    Configuring OAUTH for the ILM Store

Follow the steps below to configure OAUTH for the ILM Store

  1. Start transaction OA2C_CONFIG and create a new configuration.
  2. Use the profile ILMAZURE_STORAGE_OATUHPROF and enter the values noted from the Microsoft Azure account.

 

Access the Microsoft Azure Portal and log into your account. Open the active directory application and note down the Client ID, Client Secret and Tenant ID as shown in bellow. This is required to create an OAuth configuration in the SAP S/4HANA system.

 

Enter Any configuration Name & provide Client Id copied from above Azure portal

Hit OK

 

In the below screen add Client Secret & also modify token endpoint url.

https://login.microsoftonline.com/<tenant-id>/oauth2/v2.0/token

 

5.4  Creating the Remote Function Call (RFC)

  1. Start transaction SM59.
  2. Create a new RFC, choose a RFC destination and select connection type G – HTTP Connections to External Server.
  3. In the tab Logon and Security, select Active for SSL.
  4. Under Special Options, select HTTP 1.1 as the HTTP version.

 

Add below Host details from Azure portal

Go to Blob storage then Endpoint & copy the url

 

 

5.5     Testing the Connection

Once the configurations in the system are completed, you can test the connection to the Microsoft Azure storage account. Follow the steps below:

  1. In the store system, start transaction SE38.
  2. Execute the report RILM_STOR_TEST_AZURE with the input parameters as below.
  3. Check if the test was successful and compare your result as below.

 

 

 

6   Customizing the Origin Settings

The origin is a central element in the configuration of the store. It serves as the identifier of the data source. The customizing settings for the ILM Store can be generated using a report or they can be manually created.

 

6.1     Creating the Customizing Details Automatically

A simplified and automatic method to create the required settings for the ILM Store setup is enabled. Follow the steps below:

  •  
  1. In the ILM Store system, start transaction ILM_STOR_GEN_CUST.
  2. Enter the values for the input field.
  3. Select Microsoft Azure as the storage media.
  4. Enter the details of the RFC destination and the OAuth configuration created earlier.

 

6.2     Creating the Customizing Details Manually

If you have generated the customizing automatically this section is not required.

6.2.1     Administrative Customizing

  1. In the ILM Store system, start transaction ILM_STOR_ADM_CUST
  2. Click on Create.
  3. Enter the name of the client and the Logical File Name.
  4. Specify a name and a description for the new Administrative Origin.
  5. Click on Add Operational Origin.
  6. In the new window, enter the name and description of the Operational Origin.
  7. Chose Microsoft Azure as the Blob storage media.
  8. Enter the HTTP Connection and the OAuth client configuration created in Exporting Certificates.

6.2.2     Operational Customizing

A set of properties can be defined at the operational origin level.

To maintain the properties for an operational origin, follow these steps:

  1. Start transaction ILM_STOR_OPR_CUST.
  2. Select the client you want to edit.
  3. Click on Execute.
  4. A set of properties are listed. You can maintain the required values for this list.

 

 

6.2.3     Configuring the Routing Table

To configure the routing table, follow the steps below:

  1. Start transaction ILM_STOR_ADM_CUST and click on ConfigureRouting.
  2. Create an entry with the following details (see fig.18):
    1. System ID: <system_id>
    2. Client: <client>
    3. Data Source: <your operational origin>
  3. Save the changes.

 

 

7   Publishing the ILM Store

7.1     Activating the Internet Communication Framework (ICF) node for the ILM Store

Activate a service for the ILM Store.

 

  1. Start transaction SICF and open the service ILMSTORE under node ILM
  2. In the Logon Data tab, enter a user who has the authorization to access the ILM Store. For more information, refer to Authorizations.
  3. Right click and activate the service.

7.2     Creating a RFC Destination

A communication channel is needed to establish a connection between the SAP system and the ILM Store.

  1. Start transaction SM59.
  2. Create a new HTTP connection to the external server (type G) 
  3.  In the Technical Settings tab, enter the following values:

      Target host - Service number (port) corresponding to your system.

      Path prefix- This represents the connection between the destination and the ICF node.

            Enter the service path, which was defined in the SICF service ILMSTORE in the previous step

  1. In the Logon Data tab, enter a user who has the authorization to access the ILM Store
  2. Save and perform a connection test.

 

 

8      Testing the ILM Store Setup

After completing the setup, you must test the ILM Store.

8.1     Origin Designed for Testing Purposes

SAP offers a test origin called ARCHEB, which you can use to test the ILM Store configurations.

It is mandatory to use test reports to check the functionality of the ILM Store.

Follow the steps below:

  1. Start transaction SE38.
  2. Execute the report RILM_STOR_TEST_COPY_ARCHEB.
  3. Enter the operational origin created in Activating the Internet Communication Framework (ICF) node for the ILM Store and click on Execute.

When successful, the results should look like below

 

8.2     Test Reports

A set of reports are available to test the ILM Store setup and process.

8.2.1   Testing the Store Functionality

  1. Start transaction SE38.
  2. Execute report RILM_STOR_TEST_PF_SINGLE.
  3. Enter the value of the RFC destination created earlier(with ILMSTORE sicf service) and click on Execute.
  4. Compare the results as below.

 

8.2.2     Testing the ILM Store Customizing

  1. Start transaction SE38.
  2. Execute report RILM_STOR_TEST_AT.
  3. Enter the RFC destination created earlier and click on Execute.
  4. Compare the results with below.

 

8.3     Application Logs

The application log object for the ILM Store is ILM_STOR. Start transaction SLG1 and enter the object ILM_STOR to see the logs of all operations performed in the store.

 

9      Storage and Retention Service (SRS)

The Storage and Retention Service (SRS) is needed to store ILM enabled archive files in the ILM Store.

To use the SRS for managing ILM Stores, you need to activate it in the application system.

Note : SAP recommends installing SRS locally for performance reasons. A remote installation is possible but it is slower.

9.1     Activating the SRS

To activate the SRS, the following options are available:

  • Activate the SRS that runs locally in the application system.
  • Activate the SRS that runs on a separate (remote) system. For this option, you need a HTTP connection between the relevant systems.

9.2     Creating an ILM Store with the SRS Administration

You can create ILM Stores which are further configured to connect to storage media linked via RFC connections. Follow the steps below

  1. Start transaction ILMSTOREADM.
  2. Create a new entry.
  3. Enter the values for the ILM Store:
    1. Name: an identifying name for the store
    2. Description: descriptive text
    3. HTTP Connection: the previously created RFC destination
  4. Save the changes.

 

https://<hostname:port>/sap/bc/webdynpro/sap/ilm_store_admin?sap-client=110&sap-language=EN#

 

10       Appendix A

ILM related useful documents

ILM Store Configuration

2705663 - Collective information regarding ILM (Information Lifecycle Management)

2563024 - ILM Store - Collection of Notes

Business Functions in SAP NetWeaver

Converting Archive Files for SAP NetWeaver ILM

SAP Information Lifecycle Management NW 750

entry.title: Reassigning Scope & Solution Process in Test Preparation is now available
entry.content:
When it comes to delivering reliable solutions, testing plays a central role. But we know from customer feedback that managing test cases in SAP Cloud ALM hasn’t always been as flexible as it should be.

Until now, once a test case was created, its Scope, Solution Process, and Process Flow Diagram were locked in place. If something changed in your project setup, you often had no choice but to recreate the test case from scratch — costing time and effort.

We listened. And we’re making test case management more adaptable to the way you work.

 

What’s New

With the latest improvements for manual test cases, you’ll be able to:

  • Reassign Scope – Update a test case’s scope when project priorities or structures evolve.

  • Reassign Solution Process – Link a test case to a new process when workflows change.

  • Reassign Solution Process Flow Diagram – Connect to the most relevant diagram, so your test cases stay aligned with execution and reporting.

And the best part? You can now do this directly in the Test Preparation app, without recreating anything.

 

Why This Matters

These enhancements mean you can:

  • Save time – No more starting over when assignments change.

  • Stay flexible – Keep your test cases in sync with your evolving business processes.

  • Increase reuse – Adapt existing test cases across different processes, instead of duplicating work.

In short: less effort, more agility, and test cases that grow with your project.

 

Looking Ahead

This is just the beginning. In future waves, we’re planning even more flexibility, such as:

  • Creating test cases independent of a project / scope

  • Maintain Test Cases for Solution Activities.
  • Mass Edit in Test Preparation app.

These improvements will further reduce maintenance effort and boost consistency across projects.

 

The Bottom Line

Also this feature was requested via Customer Influence campaign https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/campaign/3501 which is strongly considered in the selection of topics to be developed. We’d love to hear from you—because the best features always start with your requests.

entry.title: Re: How to Add Text IDs for Customer Master (KNA1) in SAP...
entry.content:
Hello @hslee1 

Thank you for reaching out to the SAP Community and for your question. Within SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the capacity to create new Text IDs is restricted.

The SSCUI 105683 – Define Text Types for Sales Area Texts in Customer Master applies only to KNVV (Sales Area level).

For KNA1 (General Customer Master level), currently, no SSCUI or configuration activity is available in Central Business Configuration (CBC) to create or maintain new Text IDs..

The delivered Text IDs for KNA1 are fixed in the public cloud and cannot be extended.

For extra text fields at a general customer level, you'll need to use In-App Extensibility (Custom Fields and Logic) to add custom text fields to the customer master data, then enable them in the relevant apps, APIs, and forms.

Refer to the SAP Documentations below

SAP Learning-Configuring Special Features of Text Control

SAP Help – Extensibility in S/4HANA Cloud

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: PPIO-ENTRY creates EWM stock transfer requests despite no available stock
entry.content:
Dear all.

I am currently facing the following issue in SAP PP/SAP EWM environment: The program PPIO-ENTRY is running regularly in the background as a job and creates stock transfer requests for SAP EWM, even though there is no stock available in the affected storage types.

However, if I perform the availability check manually in the production order (CO02 → availability check), this behavior does not occur – no incorrect stock transfer requests are generated. It is noticeable that the issue seems to be related to a duplicate entry of components in the production order:

  • one item of this component has already been fully delivered,

  • the second item of the same component is still partially open.

Apparently, the background program is interpreting this constellation incorrectly and therefore triggers a faulty transfer requirement request to EWM. Has anyone of you experienced similar behavior with PPIO-ENTRY in connection with EWM integration? Could this be a customizing or program-related issue or is there perhaps even a known SAP Note/fix for this (Note 2382707 can not be implemented).

I am looking forward to hearing from you.

Kind regards,

Nicole Heinz

entry.title: S4HC Public Cloud Eclipse created CDS and AMDP
entry.content:
Hi 

we have a S/4 HANA PUBLIC CLOUD.  I am trying to understand AMDP.  Have followed this blog Understanding CDS Table Functions | by SATYASRI AKULA | SAP Innovation Hub | Medium and exactly followed the instructions .

In Eclipse the provided CDS Table Function has activated

but the AMDP class on the line FOR TABLE FUNCTION Z_JOURNAL_DATA

has a syntax error The method "GET_JE_DATA" implements the CDS table function "Z_JOURNAL_DATA". The client handling annotation for "Z_JOURNAL_DATA" is incomplete or wrong in the current language version.

I tried to fix it by including the annotations as below but I still get that same error.  Why ?

CDS table function - this activated ok

@EndUserText.label: 'Journal Data'
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED // No auth checks (default)
@ClientHandling.algorithm: #SESSION_VARIABLE //the client_element_name column is filled from the session client (sy-mandt).
@ClientHandling.type: #CLIENT_DEPENDENT //artifact ignores clients (like cross-client customizing tables in ABAP).

define table function Z_JOURNAL_DATA
with parameters @Environment.systemField: #CLIENT
     i_rclnt   : mandt,
     i_RBUKRS  : bukrs, 
     i_GJAHR   : gjahr 
    
returns {
    rclnt :mandt;
    RLDNR : fins_ledger; 
    RBUKRS: bukrs; 
    GJAHR : gjahr; 
    BELNR : belnr_d; 
  
}

implemented by method zcl_acc_je_dat=>GET_JE_DATA;

ADMP Class  - it errors on the FOR TABLE FUNCTION Z_JOURNAL_DATA.

CLASS zcl_acc_je_dat DEFINITION PUBLIC.
PUBLIC SECTION.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_je,
        rclnt  TYPE mandt,
        rldnr  TYPE FINS_LEDGER,
        rbukrs TYPE bukrs,
        gjahr  TYPE gjahr,
        belnr  TYPE belnr_d,
        rhcur  TYPE FINS_CURRH,
        END   OF ty_je,
       tt_acc_data TYPE TABLE OF ty_je.

  DATA: lv_where TYPE  string,
        lv_fin   TYPE  tt_acc_data ,
        lt_filter TYPE tt_acc_data.


INTERFACES if_amdp_marker_hdb.
    CLASS-METHODS  GET_JE_DATA 
 FOR TABLE FUNCTION Z_JOURNAL_DATA.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS zcl_acc_je_dat IMPLEMENTATION.
METHOD GET_JE_DATA BY DATABASE FUNCTION FOR HDB LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT OPTIONS READ-ONLY USING ACDOCA.

       return SELECT rclnt, rldnr, rbukrs, gjahr, belnr, rhcur FROM acdoca
      WHERE rclnt =  :i_rclnt
        AND rbukrs = :i_rbukrs
        AND gjahr =  :i_gjahr;

ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

entry.title: Clarification of basic RAP pattern
entry.content:
Hi experts,

We have a (probably) basic question about a recommended pattern in ABAP RAP model.

Context: we are developing a custom application with on-stack extensibility on S/4HANA Public Cloud. We have a custom entity ServiceMilestone, where we record the execution of a milestone for a service, that now needs to be billed. On this entity, we have a custom action CreateBillingRequest.

In the implementation of the CreateBillingRequest, we try to do the following:

1. Read the ServiceMilestone with EML based on the corresponding keys passed in the input parameter of CreateBillingRequest in a lt_servicemilestone local variable.

2. Create with EML a new entity for I_BILLINGDOCUMENTREQUESTTP, using data from the lt_servicemilestone, assigning RESULT to a local lt_result, FAILED to a local lt_failed, REPORTED to a local lt_reported and MAPPED to a local lt_mapped.

3. lt_failed, lt_reported, lt_mapped are all initial after the EML creation, and the lt_result contains the CID and the fields of the newly created I_BILLINGDOCUMENTREQUESTTP. There is no ID generated at this moment yet for the I_BILLINGDOCUMENTREQUESTTP, as it uses late numbering (key field BillingDocumentRequest is still empty).

So far so good it seems. If we do nothing else and just return from CreateBillingRequest, the LUW is committed successfully and we can see the newly created BDR in S/4.

But this is not our full need. We want to associate the new I_BILLINGDOCUMENTREQUESTTP into our entity ServiceMilestone. We created an association [0..1] in ServiceMilestone to I_BILLINGDOCUMENTREQUESTTP as BRD.

Our thinking here is (still in the call to CreateBillingRequest after steps 1, 2, 3): 

4. We have to somehow read the newly created entity with EML based on the data we got from the create (that we have in lt_result).

5. We have to add this information in the MAPPED output structure of the CreateBillingRequest, where we see that we have the ServiceMilestone field.

6. The RAP framework will commit the LUW, generate the document number for the I_BILLINGDOCUMENTREQUESTTP, save the association in our ServiceMilestone-BRD.

Is this the correct way to go or we are totally off? This should be a pretty basic pattern where a new entity with late numbering is created based on released interfaces and is then associated in our custom entity where we call the custom action.

If our way of thinking is correct, it would be great to point out how to implement correctly points 4 and 5.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: How to avoid creating condition records in SAP S4HANA?
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Private Cloud, what you’re seeing is standard External Services Management (MM‑SRV) behaviour if the system thinks it needs to store a price for later reuse. The OMFI default value (and the user parameter EVO) only controls whether prices from info records/contracts are proposed into the PO, not whether the system will create a new condition record when you save. That’s why your Z1 setting hasn’t stopped the ML35 record from appearing.

Go to your condition type in m/06 and see what settings is there for "Update" under Control Data. From your post, it seems, it is not blank. If you don’t want ME21N to create a record visible in ML35, set this field to blank for the relevant condition type in your PO pricing schema.

If your calculation schema includes a condition type with update control, it will trigger ML35 record creation.

If a service info record exists for the vendor/service combination, the system may be updating it when you save the PO. Check in ME12 (service info record) whether “Automatic creation” is active.

entry.title: Re: How to deploy Fiori to SAP S/4Hana Public Cloud using...
entry.content:
Hello @Mahesa_Lizardy 

No, it is not possible to deploy custom SAP Fiori/UI5 applications directly to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud from VS Code without access the Business Technology Platform or the Business Application Studio. The S/4HANA Public Cloud architecture only supports custom app deployment through SAP Business Technology Platform, using tools like Business Application Studio and does not provide direct transport or deployment interfaces for VS Code to the cloud system.

Develop an SAP Fiori Application and Deploy it to Cloud Foundry Using Visual Studio Code

In VS Code you can, develop your app locally using the SAP Fiori Tools extension, you can run and test the app locally. But for deployment you still need to connect to a BTP account, you have to use Cloud Foundry CLI or Fiori tools deployment command. Finally, you have to register the app to the S/4HANA cloud system through communications arrangements.

As a side note on why BAS is required. It is the official SAP supported IDE for extension in S/4HANA cloud. It provides the deployment pipelines, destination setup and integration tenant that VS Code cannot replicate by itself.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Enhancement object cannot be read
entry.content: The SAP note means that the data is corrupted. Why "not much"? Did you try it? The BAdI Definition WORKORDER_UPDATE refers to the eponymous Enhancement Spot, so add an entry R3TR ENHS WORKORDER_UPDATE in the workbench transport request (I would do a transport of copies, but if SAP says a workbench request I guess it should be fine).
